Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Media Discourse, Social Movements, and the Decline of Lynching in America.

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This dissertation investigates how the national news media talked about lynching in the US between 1880 and 1950. Preliminary results and prior historical work suggest that lynching was originally discussed by the media as a response to the crimes supposedly committed by lynching victims. Over time, however, the media came to discuss lynching as a barbaric and uncivilized practice. This research asks why such a shift in media discourse took place, and what the consequences of this change in media discourse were.

To do so the Co-PI is: 1) assembling a national-level dataset on the occurrence of lynching; 2) gathering text data on the national news media's response to those lynchings; 3) employing new computer-aided text analytic techniques, alongside more conventional comparative historical methodologies, to analyze lynching discourse; 4) analyzing anti-lynching movement campaigns, using comparative historical methods and; 5) using quantitative methods to analyze how the probability of future lynchings in specific communities was affected by negative attention to local lynchings. The proposed research will thus address two related questions: First, did social movements affect this shift in meanings? Second, did this shift in meanings have an effect on the actual practice of lynching? The findings will aid in both understanding the case at hand and the general impact of media discourse on social movements, particularly relative to issues of violence and the meaning of justice.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project resutled in a number of outcomes. First, we compiled a dataset of lynching victims across the entire US from 1883-1930. This was important since existing lynching victim datasets mostly only cover the US South, however as this dataset makes clear there were lynching victims across all regions of the US. We are sharing these data as we publish the results, currently we have included the data from the Midwest in an article submitted for publication. Ultimately, we will make the entire dataset publicly available.   

Second, this project became Seguin's dissertation, now in the process in becoming a book. The book will focus on how the lynching of atypical victims, such as Italian immigrants or black people in the northern states ultimately lead to lynching becoming a political issue that politicians and other elites worked to solve.

Third, this project served to train a number of undergraduate students in historical research methods. These students assisted Seguin in verifying lynching accounts in historical newspapers. 

Intellectually, this project will change how scholars have understood the politics of racial and ethnic violence, and illustrate new mechanisms through which racial and ethnic violence may be criticized and counteracted. The project contributes to broader impacts through the creation of research infrastructure in the form of the national lynching dataset, and brings benefits to society in illustrating effective pathways for activists and others to bring political pressure on racial violence.
